results.notes: Collected this Entoloma growing from rotting wood in a mixed woodland. Tan cap, white gills and stipe, stipe very fiberous, dense mycelial growth at base attachment to wood substrate. Salmon-orange spore print. Looks like other examples of E. rhodololium but have not seen this species growing from wood before. Would appreciate help with identification.

results.notes:
Growing on the side of a Fagus grandifolia log near Fagus grandifolia, Tsuga canadensis, Abies balsamea, Betula alleghaniensis, Picea sp., Acer sp. and Viburnum lantanoides in hardwood-conifer mixed woods. Caps hygrophanous; 9.5 to 11.5 mm wide and 5.0 to 5.3 mm tall. Gills notched. Stems 28.0 to 31.9 mm long and 1.0 to 1.4 mm wide with spiky brown basal mycelium. Clamps absent in the lamellar trama. Lamellar trama hyphae with brown intracellular pigment. Cheilocystidia clavate to obovoid with brown intracellular pigment. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores angular. Spore measurements: (14.1) 15.2 – 17.8 (19.2) × (7.2) 7.6 – 9 (9.2) µm; Q = (1.7) 1.73 – 2.18 (2.2); N = 30; Me = 16.4 × 8.4 µm; Qe = 2.

results.notes:
Growing in soil among moss, grasses and herbaceous plants under a Lonicera sp. near Viburnum sp., Crataegus sp., Abies balsamea, Prunus virginiana and Malus sp. Caps sericeous; 4.5 to 13.7 mm wide and 1.1 to 6.6 mm tall. Cap context white. Gills short decurrent; pale gray, becoming pinkish at maturity. Stems compressed and tapering; 9.5 to 15.3 mm long and 1.8 to 6.7 mm wide. Stem context white. Odor and taste not distinctive. All lamellar structures inamyloid. Lamellar cystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate and basally clamped. Spores angular and 5 to 6 sided. Many collapsed spores present. Spore measurements: (7) 8.4 – 10.5 (11.2) × (5.3) 5.7 – 6.8 (7) µm; Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 1.67 (1.7); N = 30; Me = 9.5 × 6.2 µm; Qe = 1.5.

—

results.notes:
Growing on the side of a Fagus grandifolia log and also encrusting an adjacent Huperzia sp. clubmoss. Growing near Fagus grandifolia, Tsuga canadensis, Abies balsamea, Betula alleghaniensis, Picea sp., Acer sp. and Viburnum lantanoides in hardwood-conifer mixed woods. Hymenium adhering loosely to the substrate. All structures inamyloid. Monomitic with clamped generative hyphae. Generative hyphae encrusted with crystals. Ampullate septa present. Hyphal ends encrusted with crystals forming ridges. Cystidia absent. Spores spiny and hyaline. Spore measurements: (2.9) 3.3 – 4.5 (4.9) × (2.1) 2.4 – 3.2 (3.4) µm; Q = (1.2) 1.3 – 1.5 (1.6); N = 30; Me = 3.8 × 2.7 µm; Qe = 1.4.

—

results.notes:
Habitat: mixed woodland, lowland, very moist
Substrate: leaf litter
Abundance: Few
Additional notes: Small brown mushrooms growing from leaf litter on the forest floor. Only one small cluster. 2-4 tall, caps about 1-1.5 wide. Caps planar with a depressed center and a small sharp umbo. Dark almost black umbo with velvety appearance, color growing lighter towards the outer edges of the caps. Gills are subdecurrent, white or off-white, close and many of the gills are not complete. Stipe is also brown and the color changes abruptly from stipe to gills. Color on the stipe is very pale, almost off-white at vet base if mushroom and gets steadily darker and browner towards top of stipe, chocolatey brown at base of gills. When the cap is broken open it broke easily and oozed plenty of clear liquid.

results.notes:
Collected with Jacob Kalichman. Growing on the bark of a live Quercus sect. Quercus toward the base of the tree. Growing with Hydropus sp. (DG2108218), Pulverulina ulmicola (DG2108217), Hydropus omphaliiformis, cf. Gymnopus sp. and Clitopilus sp. All surfaces of basidiocarps pure white. Caps convex to plane with depressed centers; smooth; with jagged margins; translucent-striate; 1.7 to 2.5 mm wide and 0.5 to 1.0 mm tall. Gills adnate and even with 0 to 1 tiers of lamellulae. 13 full length lamellae reaching the stem. Stems smooth; attached to white mycelial pads; 5.0 to 11.8 mm long and 0.2 to 0.4 mm wide. Odor and taste not distinctive. Pileipellis with scattered patches of thick-walled hairs. Caulocystidia absent. Clamps present. Lamellar trama inamyloid. Lamellar cystidia absent. Basidida 2-sterigmate to 4-sterigmate. Spores amyloid, hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (5.6) 5.7 – 7.9 (9) × (3.6) 3.9 – 4.8 (5.3) µm; Q = (1.2) 1.4 – 1.8 (2.1); N = 30; Me = 6.7 × 4.2 µm; Qe = 1.6.

results.notes:
In Guarea dominant mesophytic wood. Appears to be on old fruiting body of Lentinus sajor-caju on forest floor. About 3-11mm diam, short stipitate, pileus margin with hairs in handlens. Spores in the 7-8 (-10) um range, ellipsoid, many collapsed in hymenium and with refractive contents. Trama hyphae simple septate, basidia 4 spored. Many spores collapsing longitudinally, suggesting ridges (i.e. Clitopilus) but otherwise not obviously ridged and some with thickening walls, hyaline. A similar (or same) taxon found growing on leaf nearby (observation 471269) with larger spores (10+) but otherwise conforming micro anatomy of hymenium (edit: the above mentioned taxon is an amygdaliform-spored Crepidotus species). Possibly the same taxon found on bare soil and mossy rocks nearby (observation 454432).

results.notes:
Edit: This has been confirmed to be Psilocybe fimetaria. ITS and TEF1 sequences have been attached .

I am seeking help accurately identifying this mushroom. This is the second year running I have found it. Initially, I had an idea that it may be Psilocybe fimetaria, and two online forums confirmed this after I made identification posts.

This year, I have found it again, and became even more confident it was P.fimetaria. However, there is one characteristic that differentiates it from the literature I could find online: the lack of clearly defined annulus, which Stamets and Walting put in their descriptions of P.fimetaria. These mushrooms often have a ring zone / collar of dark spores where an annulus would be. I am wondering if it is possible that the American P.fimetaria have such annulus, and European P.Fimetaria does not? Different species? Same species but different variants?

Therefore, would somebody who knows more that I please be able to offer their thoughts to exactly what this mushroom is. Personally, I am 90% sure it is P.fimetaria and but there is a little bit of doubt that it may be P. liniformans.
Some more info:

- Grows in similar habitat to P.semilanceata
- Fruits in temps under 15 Celsius and after rain
- Found on decomposing cow dung
- Seperable gelatenous pellicle
- Dark purple spore print
- Hygrophanous cap, fruits gregariously, farinaceous odor etc…

More info can be provided in the comments.

results.notes:
Collected and photo documented on FB by Scott Ulrich, who was on his honeymoon when he found this! Sadly, it was not saved.

Found in a mixed hardwood/conifer forest.

Although currently classified in section Phalloideae, this may well be something in the new Cui section Roanokensis, which has several “phalloideae-like” members. If so, it would lack amatoxins.

With a specimen, it would be easy to test that theory with the brand new Amatoxtest. Fingers crossed!

Scott gave me permission to post his finds here.

results.notes: This striking Cortinarius was found on an NJMA foray in the Pine Barrens by a club member. It was already somewhat dry when found. The scruffy cap changed from rose to purple with KOH when blotted. Gills are notched and attached. Evidence of a rusty brown cortina is present on the stem. The context of the cap and stem are yellowish. The spore print was rusty brown. Spores were elliptical and ranged in size from 5.5-7.5×3.5-4.5 microns. A dried specimen will be sent to Igor Safonov for possible sequencing through the New Jersey Mycological Association.

results.notes:
On well-rotted wood making contact with the ground.
The immature fruit bodies pictured were allowed to mature on my front porch.
Spores minutely warty. In a side-by-side comparison at 400x with L. pyriforme spores, the difference is seen. Head on the perlatum spores exhibit darkened scratchy marks (on account of interference with the light source) and some very thin small warts are barely visible along the perimeters. The pyriforme spores are clearly completely smooth, ie. lacking in the subtle ornamentation. These features are not viewable in a photo snapped through one eyepiece of my binocular scope.
Although L. perlatum fruit bodies are generally found on the ground, like other primarily terrestrial fungi the mycelium occasionally penetrates and climbs up/through decaying wood.
results.location_name: Ricketts Glen State Park, Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes: I found this last night close to a larch tree on my property. One of the nicest Agaricus specimens I have ever found. I used a key to Agaricus mushrooms from mushroomexpert.com and ultimately came to Agaricus subrufescens but I’m not 100% confident on that. It seems like a good possibility though due to the fact that there was evident yellow bruising on the cap margin but no yellow staining when a section was sliced from the stem base. It is also fairly robust which also seems to point me in that direction. No considerable odor/scent was detected but perhaps my sense of smell just isn’t that great. I know Agaricus subrufescens should have a smell similar to almonds. Thanks for any help!

results.notes:
Found the mushrooms on a dead tree lying on the forest floor, in a mixed wood forest. They were in clusters of 4. Date found :Oct. 6, 2021. I took the spore print: White.

I took the images at home so I do not have the images at the location where I picked them.

Picture mushroom app points to Elm oyster mushroom. On the hand, many mushroom sites indicate that elm oyster grows on live trees, which is not the case with this mushroom.
I also check mycoquebec site, there seems to be two very similar elm mushrooms, Hypsizygus tessulatus and Hypsizygus ulmarius. According to this site they can be found both on living and death trees.

So it seems there are some conflicting info. about Elm oyster.

results.notes: Found in a hardwood dominated forest with some coniferous trees. The specimens were found on a half submerged heavily decayed log. Oak or Birch is likely. Red fibrous caps when young growing into large (5") orange caps. Green brusing is noticed on some young fruits. Dark brown brusing otherwise noted. Smell is not distinguishable. Ring or annular zone noticed on most with a heavy deposit of orange spores. Thick, strong but short stipes relative to cap size. Light yellow gills when young becoming orange when older. Heavy spore depositor. The green color seen on some of the older caps is mold.

results.notes:
I spotted this large fruiting for it’s fairy ring, probably 2 to 3 meters in diameter, I did not measure it. The brown, slimey cap fades to a lighter orange-brown mostly irregular round cap and is very sticky-wet. It has a separable pellicle. Flesh inside cap is white and fresh smelling of mushroom. Hymenium is yellow pored, fading to medium brown. No weeping is present. There is NO annulus persisting on stipe or cap. Stipe is solid and stout, white fading to yellow at cap, with reddish glandular spotting. No staining on hands from handling. White rhizomorphs present. Fruits range from 3 cm to 15 cm across cap, 6 to 8 cm tall, average being about 7 cm across and 8 cm tall. Spore print is light brown to cinnamon brown. Specimens are prints only.
Habitat is a P. strobus (White Pine) treeline near a ditch. Fruiting is clearly ectomycorrhizal, spreading out from pines on the root systems and forming fairy rings in the grass. Fruiting in area are other Suillus species. There was a soaking rain 3 or 4 nights prior.
Species may be previously misidentified as B. granulatus.
